verses.text: And King David said to all the assembly, "Solomon my son, whom God has chosen, is young and inexperienced, and the work is great, for the temple is not for man, but for the LORD God."
verses.comment: Reflects David's charge regarding Solomon's age and the temple's divine purpose.

verses.text: So with all my power I have provided for the house of my God: gold for the objects of gold, silver for those of silver, bronze for those of bronze, iron for those of iron, and wood for those of wood; as well as onyx stones, stones for settings, stones of turquoise, variegated stones, and every kind of precious stone, and marble in abundance.
verses.comment: Modernizes terms for precious stones; 'marble' instead of 'parian marble.'

verses.text: Moreover, because of my devotion to the house of my God, I give my own private treasure of gold and silver for the house of my God, in addition to everything I have already prepared for the holy temple.
verses.comment: Clarifies 'devotion'; maintaining David's personal commitment.

verses.text: Three thousand talents of gold, gold of Ophir, and seven thousand talents of refined silver, for overlaying the walls of the buildings;
verses.comment: Uses weight terms in 'talents,' unchanged for historical accuracy.

verses.text: gold for the things of gold, and silver for the things of silver, and for every kind of work to be done by the craftsmen. Who then is willing to consecrate himself today to the LORD?"
verses.comment: Preserves David's challenge to consecrate themselves.

verses.text: Then the leaders of the clans, the leaders of the tribes of Israel, the commanders of thousands and of hundreds, and the supervisors over the king's work offered willingly;
verses.comment: Translates 'offered willingly' for clarity.

verses.text: And they gave for the service of God's house five thousand talents and ten thousand darics of gold, ten thousand talents of silver, eighteen thousand talents of bronze, and one hundred thousand talents of iron.
verses.comment: 'Darics' are included as units of gold, consistent with ancient measures.

verses.text: And whoever had precious stones gave them to the treasury of the house of the LORD, under the care of Jehiel the Gershonite.
verses.comment: Names 'Jehiel the Gershonite' for accuracy.

verses.text: Then the people rejoiced, because they had offered willingly, with a whole heart they had offered freely to the LORD; and King David also rejoiced greatly.
verses.comment: Preserves 'whole heart' in offering freely.

verses.text: Therefore David blessed the LORD in the sight of all the assembly, and David said, "Blessed are you, O LORD, the God of Israel our father, forever and ever."
verses.comment: Maintains David's prayer form.

verses.text: Yours, O LORD, is the greatness and the power and the glory and the victory and the majesty; for all that is in the heavens and on the earth is yours. Yours is the kingdom, O LORD, and you are exalted as head over all.
verses.comment: This verse echoes language from the Lord's Prayer (Matt. 6:13).

verses.text: Both riches and honor come from you, and you rule over all. In your hand are power and might, and in your hand it is to make great and to give strength to all.
verses.comment: Retains the parallel structure of Hebrew poetry.

verses.text: And now we thank you, our God, and praise your glorious name.
verses.comment: Simple, direct praise; matches original intent.

verses.text: But who am I, and who are my people, that we should be able to give so generously as this? For everything comes from you, and we have given you only what comes from your hand.
verses.comment: Retains phrase 'who am I' for humility.

verses.text: For we are strangers before you and sojourners, as all our ancestors were. Our days on the earth are like a shadow, and there is no abiding.
verses.comment: Includes 'no abiding' for poetic sense.

verses.text: O LORD our God, all this abundance that we have provided to build you a house for your holy name comes from your hand and is all your own.
verses.comment: Changes 'thine own' to 'your own' for modern English.

verses.text: I know, my God, that you test the heart and take pleasure in uprightness. In the uprightness of my heart I have offered all these things willingly, and now I have seen your people, who are present here, offering willingly to you.
verses.comment: Phrase 'test the heart' direct from Hebrew.

verses.text: O LORD, God of Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, our fathers, keep forever such purposes and thoughts in the hearts of your people, and direct their hearts toward you.
verses.comment: Keeps the three patriarchs as named in Hebrew.

verses.text: Grant to Solomon my son a whole heart to keep your commandments, your testimonies, and your statutes, doing all of them, and to build the temple for which I have made preparation."
verses.comment: Uses 'whole heart'; preserves 'commandments, testimonies, and statutes.'

verses.text: Then David said to all the assembly, "Bless the LORD your God." And all the assembly blessed the LORD, the God of their fathers, and bowed low and paid homage to the LORD and to the king.
verses.comment: Bowing and homage are included as distinct acts.

verses.text: And they offered sacrifices to the LORD, and on the next day offered burnt offerings to the LORD: a thousand bulls, a thousand rams, a thousand lambs, with their drink offerings, and sacrifices in abundance for all Israel.
verses.comment: Animal list kept as given; 'drink offerings' specified.

verses.text: And they ate and drank before the LORD that day with great joy. And they made Solomon the son of David king a second time, and anointed him as ruler for the LORD and Zadok as priest.
verses.comment: 'A second time' included for historical sequence.

verses.text: Then Solomon sat on the throne of the LORD as king instead of David his father. He prospered, and all Israel obeyed him.
verses.comment: Phrase 'throne of the LORD' retained from Hebrew.

verses.text: All the leaders and the mighty men, and also all the sons of King David, pledged themselves to King Solomon.
verses.comment: Adds clarity to 'pledged themselves.'

verses.text: And the LORD made Solomon exceedingly great in the sight of all Israel, and bestowed on him royal majesty such as had never been on any king in Israel before him.
verses.comment: 'Royal majesty' as a phrase modernized.

verses.text: Now David the son of Jesse reigned over all Israel.
verses.comment: Direct, historical summary.

verses.text: The period that he reigned over Israel was forty years. He reigned seven years in Hebron and thirty-three years in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Numbers unchanged; cities named as in original.

verses.text: And David died at a good old age, full of days, riches, and honor. And Solomon his son reigned in his place.
verses.comment: Retains 'good old age, full of days.'

verses.text: Now the acts of King David, from the first to the last, are written in the chronicles of Samuel the seer, the chronicles of Nathan the prophet, and the chronicles of Gad the seer,
verses.comment: Changes 'book' to 'chronicles,' parallel to the Hebrew.

verses.text: with all his reign and his power, and the circumstances that befell him and Israel and all the kingdoms of the lands.
verses.comment: Summarizes David's life and broader context.
